awd_titl_txt: Workshop to Revise the Liberal Art of Science
awd_abstract_narration:
In 1990, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) published the groundbreaking document, "The Liberal Art of Science," which recommended that all college students should take more science courses.  This book and associated program argued that science pervades all aspects of contemporary human existence and that our nation's future economy and security and the quality of individual lives depend on the public's understanding of scientific developments.  The importance of science for all remains true today.  Since 1990, however, the science and science education communities have made significant discoveries about how students learn, how to engage a broader spectrum of students in science, what are effective pedagogical methods to teach science, and what scientifically literate citizens and future scientists should know and be able to do.  In 1990, many Americans were noted to have little understanding of science or how it affected their lives, and many students, especially from underrepresented groups, had limited access to or incentives to pursue science as a degree or career.  These major issues still hold true in 2018.  Thus, the revision of "The Liberal Art of Science" is an important and timely endeavor, capitalizing on recent breakthroughs while addressing continuing problems.  The workshop will bring together scientists and science educators to outline and begin writing an updated "Liberal Art of Science" and to plan for the widespread implementation of contemporary recommendations for teaching and learning science by improving existing science courses and not simply trying to add more courses to a students' already crowded curriculum.  Workshop participants will have diverse research interests in science, science education, faculty professional development, and science literacy.  They will also represent major scientific and science education organizations and institutional associations actively engaged in professional development of their members.        

Participants at the workshop will have significant obligations before attending the meeting at the headquarters of the AAAS in Washington, D.C.  Each person will be asked either to draft an outline of a chapter in the new book or prepare a presentation for the workshop itself based on their interests and expertise.  In addition, each person will identify one or two exemplary individuals or programs that use active learning methods, increase scientific literacy of students, or focus on learning outcomes that prepare students for a world that is increasingly influenced by science and technology.  The workshop, which will extend over parts of three days, will be a series of presentations, discussions, and small working groups and will result in an outline of the entire new document and a plan to disseminate and implement new recommendations for change.         

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This was a collaborative project with Dr. James Collins of Arizona State University.  We asked, “How do science faculty best prepare students, whether or not they are science majors, for their future filled with decisions they will have to make regarding science-related personal, professional, and societal questions and issues?”  The original document, "The Liberal Art of Science (AAAS, 1990)" was published over three decades ago, and one of its core messages was that scientific literacy was an essential characteristic for all Americans to possess--not only for individual well-being, but for the economic health of the U.S. as well.  Our task was to re-examine the original LAS document in the context of the modern world.  The recent pandemic illustrated the need for citizens to have access to validated scientific and health information and to possess the ability and desire to use that information to make informed decisions.  Scientific literacy is as important today as decades ago.  In response to this continuing need we developed a model of scientific literacy (see attached image) that prepares students to use the science concepts and skills they gain in classes throughout their lives.  This model is holistic because it requires students to gain essential content knowledge within a scientific discipline as well as critical and scientific thinking skills.  It is also designed to help students see the benefits of science, to develop a life-long interest in science, and to understand how to address future science-related issues and problems while inoculating students against the potentially confusing misuses of scientific information to which they are frequently confronted.  The model was reviewed at several major science education meetings, including the 2023 Gordon Research Conference on Undergraduate Biology Education Research, an annual conference of the National Association of Biology Teachers, and an annual meeting of SENCER (Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities).  The model was also used as an organizing construct for the large project, IGELS (Interactions in General Education Life Science courses).  It is important for all faculty members in science to adopt scientific literacy as a major learning outcome of their courses. Our work suggests that there is an opportunity for the science education community to move forward as a whole, collaborating where possible, but also reinforcing the individual work of all.  For many college students, including future politicians, journalists, citizens, voters, and teachers, there may be only a few courses where they experience the processes and products of science, so these classes must be memorable, useful, and impactful. There is a significant role that science- and science-education societies can play in implementing new recommendations regarding scientific literacy, in building public understanding and trust of science, promoting informed public policy, and empowering student success as we address the grand challenges facing contemporary science and society.  We recommend a new collaborative effort that engages all the players in science and science education in creating a pathway to implementing recommendations for quality science education with a unified vision for developing useful, relevant scientific literacy for all students.
